title: NHS boss handed £200,000 redundancy from regional body only to return
text:
Ian Stidston was handed a hefty £200,000 redundancy package by NHS's Southend Clinical Commissioning Group

A senior NHS boss who was handed a hefty £200,000 redundancy package has sparked outrage after re-joining the health service just months later.

Ian Stidston was formerly accountable officer - effectively the chief executive - of the NHS's Southend Clinical Commissioning Group until he lost his job in April 2018.

Then, he was handed the bumper package of about £150,000 for redundancy and £50,000 in lieu of notice.

But it has now been revealed that he then joined Thurrock's Clinical Commissioning Group and is currently its interim director of commissioning.

And the two commissioning groups are set to merge under plans for a new Mid and South Essex Clinical Commissioning Group, prompting confusion over why he was given the huge payment before later re-joining the NHS.

Jeremy Hutton, policy analyst at the TaxPayers' Alliance, said: 'It is unfortunately not uncommon for senior public sector employees to receive eye-watering handouts on being made redundant.

'What is extraordinary, however, is for that same employee to return to effectively the same organisation.'

Mr Stidston earned a salary of between £105,000 and £110,000 as accountable officer at Southend Clinical Commissioning Group.

According to the commissioning group's remuneration report, he received a 'redundancy payment in the £150,000 to £155,000 band' and a payment 'in lieu of notice' in the £50,000 to £55,000 band.

Mr Stidston has now been revealed that he then joined Thurrock's Clinical Commissioning Group and is currently its interim director of commissioning

A spokesman for Southend Clinical Commissioning Group insisted the payment was in line with national protocols.

He said: 'NHS Southend and NHS Castle Point and Rochford Clinical Commissioning Groups formed a joint management team to streamline commissioning that has ultimately reduced running costs.

'This process resulted in the need to make changes to roles and responsibilities of existing staff and put in place some temporary staffing arrangements to ensure clinical commissioning groups' legal duties were met.

'This also resulted in redundancies.'

Over the past two years, Mr Stidston's former employer, Southend Clinical Commissioning Group, has been criticised over the scale of its' £7million deficit and was placed in special measures from October 2017 until July 2019.

The special measures also came after healthcare bosses were previously accused of wasting money when it emerged that some of the highest paid directors were only employed on a temporary basis.

A spokesman for NHS Thurrock Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) said: 'NHS Thurrock CCG and NHS Southend CCG are entirely separate organisations within the NHS.

'Any decisions around redundancies or the hiring of new staff by each CCG are made independently from each other and follow rigorous NHS rules and a thorough application process.'

'The CCGs in Mid and South Essex have drawn up plans to merge, however these will not be completed until Spring 2021.

'Until that time, NHS Thurrock CCG will continue to operate as an independent organisation with its own management and governance structures.'
description: Ian Stidston was formerly accountable officer at Southend CCG until he lost his job in April 2018. But it has now been revealed that he then joined Thurrock's CCG as an interim director.
